sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change in a process
message_1: A thermodynamic system undergoes an isothermal expansion at a constant temperature of 500 K, during which it releases 1500 J of heat to the surroundings. The final volume of the system is 0.05 m³ and its initial volume was 0.02 m³. Determine the entropy change of the system during this process.
message_2:
To determine the entropy change of the system during this isothermal expansion, we can use the formula:

ΔS = Q/T

where ΔS is the entropy change, Q is the heat exchanged, and T is the temperature.

Since the system releases 1500 J of heat to the surroundings, the heat exchanged is -1500 J (negative because it's released). The temperature is given as 500 K.

Now, we can plug the values into the formula:

ΔS = (-1500 J) / (500 K)

ΔS = -3 J/K

The entropy change of the system during this isothermal expansion is -3 J/K.
